study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether bariatric surgery could interrupt intergenerational transmission of disease risk by modifying paternal metabolic health before conception.
results_summary: The study suggests bariatric surgery as a potential intervention to reduce intergenerational disease risk by improving paternal metabolic health, though specific outcomes were not detailed. The abstract highlights sperm epigenetic markers as a mechanism for disease transmission.
population_specificity: Fathers with metabolic diseases (e.g., obesity, diabetes) prior to conception.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether the improvement of diabetic kidney disease in patients with type 2 diabetes undergoing metabolic surgery depends on weight loss.
results_summary: The study found no correlation between weight loss and improved renal injury (measured by changes in urinary albumin-creatinine ratio or albuminuria), suggesting metabolic surgery improves diabetic kidney disease independent of weight loss. Other mechanisms, such as modified adipokine balance and reduced systemic inflammation, likely contribute to these benefits.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes undergoing metabolic surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the influence of preoperative HbA1c levels on outcomes following sleeve gastrectomy (SG) in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found that preoperative HbA1c levels influenced postoperative outcomes, though the abstract does not specify the nature or direction of these effects. The conclusion suggests HbA1c may be a predictor for SG outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent sleeve gastrectomy in seven referral centers for bariatric surgery, excluding revision surgeries, combined procedures, or those with missing data.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if protein oxidation biomarkers in adipose tissue could predict weight-loss success after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Higher levels of carboxyethyl-lysine (CEL) and 2-succinocystein (2SC) in adipose tissue before surgery correlated with greater weight loss in both human and animal models, suggesting these biomarkers predict bariatric surgery outcomes.
population_specificity: Sixty-five individuals with obesity undergoing bariatric surgery and a diet-induced obesity animal model.
study_duration: 2 months post-diet treatment in the animal model; human follow-up duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) and laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB) in terms of weight loss and morbimortality over a 36-month follow-up period.
results_summary: LSG was found non-inferior to LRYGB for weight loss and had a lower risk of major complications, but gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) increased in the LSG group while decreasing in the LRYGB group.
population_specificity: Patients with a mean age of 41.1±11.1 years and an average preoperative BMI of 45.3±5.5 kg/m² in France.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the technical success, leak resolution, and reoperation rates of endoscopic therapy for sleeve gastrectomy leaks (SGLs).
results_summary: Endoscopic therapy resolved leaks in 72.9% of patients, avoiding surgical revision, but 21.7% required surgical intervention, particularly those with acute/chronic leaks or abscesses. Adverse events occurred in 11.5% of sessions, mostly managed endoscopically.
population_specificity: 85 patients (70 women, mean age 42.6 years) with SGLs treated at eight academic endoscopy centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether the controlled attenuation parameter (CAP) using the FibroScan XL probe overestimates liver steatosis in morbidly obese patients and to determine if reprocessing data at greater depths improves accuracy.
results_summary: CAP was overestimated in half of morbidly obese patients using the standard XL probe, but adjusting the measurement depth corrected this. Reprocessed CAP (CAPa) showed significant improvement in diagnosing steatosis stages, with AUROC curves of 0.86, 0.83, and 0.79 for S≥1, S≥2, and S=3, respectively.
population_specificity: 249 severely obese patients admitted for sleeve gastrectomy.
study_duration: CAP measurement performed within 15 days preceding liver biopsy during surgery.

study_goal: To evaluate the cost-effectiveness of bariatric surgery compared with standard treatment for obesity-related comorbidities in the Colombian context.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was cost-effective for diabetes and hypertension cohorts, dominant (more effective and less costly) for sleep apnea, but less effective than nonsurgical treatment for dyslipidemia.
population_specificity: Obese patients in Colombia with comorbidities (diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, or sleep apnea).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of standard and distal gastric bypass on bone turnover markers and secondary hyperparathyroidism two years after surgery.
results_summary: Both standard and distal gastric bypass led to significant increases in bone turnover markers, with no significant differences between the two procedures. Secondary hyperparathyroidism was more prevalent after distal gastric bypass but did not significantly impact bone turnover markers.
population_specificity: Patients with a body mass index (BMI) of 50-60 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and success rates of different treatment strategies for staple line leaks following sleeve gastrectomy.
results_summary: Successful initial management rates were 62% for endoscopic treatment, 76% for surgery, and 82% for conservative treatment. Seven deaths occurred, all in patients who underwent surgery as initial management.
population_specificity: Patients with staple line leaks following laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically assess the effects of bariatric surgery and other weight-loss interventions on short-chain fatty acid (SCFA) concentrations in overweight or obese adults.
results_summary: The study found that SCFA concentrations either remained unchanged or decreased significantly following weight loss, particularly with low-carbohydrate dietary interventions. However, results were inconsistent, and most studies had high risk of bias and small sample sizes.
population_specificity: Overweight (BMI 25-29.9 kg/m²) or obese (BMI ≥30 kg/m²) adults aged ≥18 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pharmacokinetics and tissue penetration of fosfomycin in obese versus non-obese surgical patients.
results_summary: Obese patients showed lower peak plasma concentrations and higher volume of distribution for fosfomycin compared to non-obese patients, with significantly reduced drug exposure in subcutaneous tissue. The tissue/plasma ratio was also lower in obese patients, indicating altered pharmacokinetics in this population.
population_specificity: Obese patients (BMI 38-50 kg/m²) undergoing bariatric surgery and non-obese patients (BMI 0-29 kg/m²) undergoing major intra-abdominal surgery.
effective_dosage: Single intravenous short infusion of 8 g fosfomycin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the impact of differences between PTH assays on clinical guidelines, including those related to PTH measurements in patients after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract notes that guidelines for patients after bariatric surgery specify absolute cutoff values for PTH, but the impact of different generation assays is unknown due to lack of direct comparisons.
population_specificity: Patients after bariatric surgery (mentioned in the context of PTH measurement guidelines).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms behind weight loss after Laparoscopic Gastric Plication (LGP) by analyzing changes in the serum proteome post-surgery.
results_summary: The study found that LGP alters serum protein levels, particularly affecting lipid and inflammatory pathways, with significant changes observed at 1-2 months post-surgery. Four newly identified proteins (SRGN, FETUB, LCP1, CFP) were linked to weight loss, suggesting systemic effects beyond simple food restriction.
population_specificity: 16 obese individuals who underwent LGP.
study_duration: Follow-up at 1-2 months (T1) and 4-5 months (T2) post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the clinical presentation and characteristics of SGLT2i-associated diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) in the surgical setting, particularly focusing on bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study identified 13 cases of DKA (12 euglycaemic and one hyperglycaemic) in bariatric surgery patients, with very-low-calorie diets noted as a precipitating factor in 10 cases. All patients with outcome data recovered completely, but EDKA may be under-recognized due to atypical presentation.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery who were on SGLT2 inhibitors.
study_duration: Varied from a few hours up to 6 weeks post-operation
interactions: Sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 inhibitors (SGLT2i) and very-low-calorie diets were noted as potential precipitating factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical assessment and treatment strategies for pediatric severe obesity, including the role of metabolic and bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is effective and durable for pediatric severe obesity but is not a scalable treatment strategy. Lifestyle modification alone is insufficient for significant BMI reduction in most cases.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with severe obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the most common elements of Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) protocols for intra-abdominal procedures, including bariatric surgery, to identify best practices for perioperative care.
results_summary: The study found that ERAS protocols, when applied individually based on patient needs, optimize perioperative care by breaking traditional hospital silos and coordinating multidisciplinary interventions. The review highlighted elements of ERAS protocols that provided the best outcomes and could be generalized across intra-abdominal procedures.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing intra-abdominal surgical procedures, including bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and outcomes of metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) in children and adolescents.
results_summary: MBS was found to be safe for adolescents, with sustainable long-term weight loss and improvement in obesity-related comorbidities. A recent trial showed BMI reductions of 3.8 kg/m².
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare changes in levothyroxine (LT4) dosage requirements in hypothyroid patients two years after undergoing either laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB) or laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG).
results_summary: The study found that LT4 dosage decreased significantly in the LSG group but remained stable in the LRYGB group after two years. Weight-based LT4 dose increased in the LRYGB group but showed no significant change in the LSG group, indicating different LT4 requirement patterns between the two surgical methods.
population_specificity: Obese patients with hypothyroidism who underwent bariatric surgery (22 LRYGB, 13 LSG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the metabolic changes induced by bariatric surgery, focusing on gut architectural changes, inflammatory tone, and gut microbiota modifications.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery is highly effective for weight reduction and metabolic improvements, with 60% of patients achieving diabetes remission. It modulates systemic and adipose tissue inflammation as well as gut microbiota dysbiosis.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity and associated comorbidities, particularly type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the pharmacokinetics of gentamicin in morbidly obese and non-obese individuals to develop a dosing algorithm for adequate drug exposure across body weights.
results_summary: The study found that total body weight was a key determinant for gentamicin clearance and volume of distribution, leading to a proposed dosing algorithm. A two-compartment model best described the pharmacokinetic data.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese individuals undergoing bariatric surgery and non-obese healthy volunteers.
effective_dosage: Obese: 5 mg/kg based on lean body weight; non-obese: 5 mg/kg based on total body weight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize current evidence on the cost-effectiveness of bariatric surgery for obese individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Most studies concluded that bariatric surgery is cost-effective for obese individuals with type 2 diabetes, with some studies outside the USA finding it cost-saving. Many US insurers cover the procedure for this population with a BMI ≥ 35 kg/m².
population_specificity: Obese individuals with type 2 diabetes and BMI ≥ 35 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of bariatric surgery on maternal and infant health outcomes of pregnancy compared to BMI-matched controls without surgery.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery before pregnancy reduced infant birth weight but did not affect maternal gestational weight gain or Apgar scores. Surgery did not increase risks of adverse outcomes like miscarriage, stillbirth, preterm birth, or infant complications, though effects on maternal complications and birth weight categories were inconsistent.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with a history of bariatric surgery and BMI-matched controls without surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify preoperative characteristics of patients who fail to attend 2-year follow-up visits after laparoscopic gastric bypass surgery.
results_summary: The study found that younger age, male sex, depression, history of smoking, being single, and being a first-generation immigrant were associated with higher risk of missing follow-up, while elementary occupation was linked to lower risk.
population_specificity: 2495 patients who underwent laparoscopic gastric bypass surgery in Sweden.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a non-invasive scoring system using clinical and biochemical parameters to predict the risk of NASH in obese individuals undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study identified five independent predictors (HbA1c, AST, ALT, liver span on USG, and serum triglycerides) to create a scoring system for NASH risk, with 85.87% sensitivity and 75.35% diagnostic accuracy. It confirmed a significant association of NAFLD with obesity and provided a tool to identify high-risk individuals.
population_specificity: Obese Indians (290 patients) undergoing bariatric/metabolic surgery.
study_duration: Data collected pre-operatively between September 2017 and October 2018.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to comprehensively evaluate the efficacy and safety of various bariatric procedures, comparing their effectiveness in excess weight loss and diabetes mellitus remission.
results_summary: BPD-DS, RYGB, and SG showed superior efficacy for excess weight loss and diabetes remission compared to standard-of-care, with SG having a lower risk of adverse events than RYGB. At 3 years, RYGB and SG maintained superior efficacy for weight loss, and all procedures except adjustable gastric banding were effective long-term for diabetes remission.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: Follow-up periods ranged from 6 months to 5 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate associations between childhood maltreatment severity/types and lifetime psychopathology among adults with severe obesity awaiting bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that among women with obesity, presence/greater severity of childhood mental or physical abuse/neglect was associated with higher risks of psychopathology, suicidal ideation/behavior, and antidepressant use. Childhood sexual abuse was independently linked to suicidal ideation/behavior and antidepressant use.
population_specificity: Adults with severe obesity (302 females, 66 males) awaiting bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of bariatric surgery on risk factors for atherosclerosis, including insulin resistance, hyperinsulinaemia, and lipid profiles.
results_summary: Twelve months after bariatric surgery, patients showed significant reductions in body mass index, insulin resistance, hyperinsulinaemia, and interleukin-6 levels, suggesting improvements in atherogenic risk factors. The study highlights the potential of bariatric surgery as a model for understanding the link between insulin resistance and atherosclerosis.
population_specificity: 40 patients (20 with type 2 diabetes mellitus) undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between obesity and chronic kidney disease and assess the role of bariatric surgery in improving access to kidney transplantation for high-BMI patients.
results_summary: The review found no definitive evidence supporting BMI-based transplant eligibility cut-offs and noted an obesity paradox where obese patients had better survival pre-transplant. Promising but inconclusive results for bariatric surgery were observed.
population_specificity: Obese patients with chronic kidney disease, particularly those being considered for kidney transplantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) oxygen therapy reduces postoperative hypoxemia in morbidly obese patients after bariatric surgery compared to conventional oxygen therapy.
results_summary: HFNC significantly reduced postoperative hypoxemia (28.6% vs. 80.0%) and atelectasis (31% vs. 77%) compared to standard care, with no severe postoperative pulmonary complications reported.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: HFNC or conventional oxygen therapy applied during the first three postoperative hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the mechanisms and outcomes of GLP-1 neuromodulation in relation to energy homeostasis and feeding behavior, providing a foundation for future research.
results_summary: The study highlights the multifaceted actions of GLP-1, including its peripheral and neural effects, which influence energy homeostasis and feeding behavior. It emphasizes the hormone's potential in obesity and diabetes treatment due to its incretin effect and neuromodulatory capabilities.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on GLP-1 mechanisms rather than a specific human or animal population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine associations between preoperative history of infertility and postbariatric surgery conception rates in women.
results_summary: Women with a preoperative history of infertility and nulliparity had significantly higher postoperative conception rates and early conception rates compared to those without such a history, along with a higher risk of unprotected intercourse.
population_specificity: Women aged 18-44 with no history of menopause, hysterectomy, or hormone replacement therapy who underwent bariatric surgery.
study_duration: Follow-up was up to 7 years (median 6.5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare changes in body composition, specifically fat mass and lean mass, between bariatric surgery (AGB and RYGB) and medical weight loss in individuals with type 2 diabetes and BMI 30-39.9 kg/m².
results_summary: AGB resulted in greater loss of lean mass and visceral adipose tissue (VAT) compared to medical weight loss, while RYGB also showed a tendency for greater VAT loss. Both surgical methods demonstrated superior effects on VAT reduction compared to medical weight loss.
population_specificity: 12 female participants (75% African American) with type 2 diabetes and BMI 30-39.9 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of bariatric surgery on glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes and BMI < 30 kg/m².
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that bariatric surgery reduced BMI and waist circumference, improved glycemic control, and decreased HbA1c levels in Asian patients with type 2 diabetes and BMI < 30 kg/m² over 6, 12, and 24-month follow-ups.
population_specificity: Asian patients with type 2 diabetes and BMI < 30 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of bariatric surgery on maternal and neonatal insulin resistance (IR) and neonatal body fat composition in pregnant women.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery was associated with reduced maternal IR, lower neonatal birthweight, and decreased neonatal body fat, but no improvement in neonatal cord IR. Correlations between maternal and neonatal IR and neonatal IR and body fat were absent in the post-bariatric surgery group.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with a history of bariatric surgery (n=41) and pregnant women with similar early pregnancy BMI but no history of bariatric surgery (n=82).
study_duration: Not specified (evaluated at 28 weeks of gestation and at birth)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of bariatric surgery on reward-related behaviors, particularly changes in taste, food cravings, and the risk of substance use disorder (SUD), while investigating potential underlying neural and hormonal mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery leads to long-term weight loss and changes in eating behavior, but also increases the risk of SUD, especially alcohol use disorder (AUD). Different surgical procedures (RYGB and SG) had varying effects on alcohol consumption, suggesting gut-brain signaling plays a role in reward regulation.
population_specificity: Humans and rats (preclinical studies mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery and abdominal lipectomy in reducing cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk and related morbidity and mortality in obese and metabolic syndrome patients.
results_summary: The study found that while bariatric surgery (Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy) reduced CVD risk factors, it showed limited improvements in cardiovascular function or CVD-related mortality. Abdominal lipectomy demonstrated more consistent improvements in CVD risk factors and cardiovascular function, but both approaches lacked comprehensive exploration of their cardiovascular benefits.
population_specificity: Obese and metabolic syndrome patients, with specific focus on diabetic or >50-year-old individuals for gastric bypass.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of bariatric surgery on liver fat content and inflammation in patients with NAFLD/NASH.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery, through significant weight loss, was found to improve liver fat and inflammation in patients with NAFLD/NASH. The abstract suggests it is an effective intervention for these conditions.
population_specificity: Patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) or nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), particularly those with obesity and insulin resistance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of bariatric surgery as a treatment for NASH in morbidly obese patients where lifestyle modifications failed.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery resolves NASH in morbidly obese patients when lifestyle changes are insufficient, and it is recommended for this population. Pharmacotherapies are also valuable, though no FDA-approved drugs exist yet, and several agents are under clinical trial investigation.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients with NASH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and challenges of using Transversus Abdominal Plane (TAP) block as part of multimodal analgesia for morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that TAP block's efficacy in morbidly obese patients is still under discussion due to challenges in ultrasound visualization and potential risks of inadequate needle positioning. It highlights the need for further evidence to balance the benefits and drawbacks of TAP block in this population.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association of female obesity with live birth rates following IVF and whether weight loss, including through bariatric surgery, could reverse the negative effects.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that female obesity significantly decreases the probability of live birth following IVF, with poorer prognosis when obesity is associated with polycystic ovary syndrome. The study suggests further evaluation of whether weight loss via lifestyle changes or bariatric surgery could reverse this effect.
population_specificity: Obese women (BMI ≥ 30 kg/m²) undergoing IVF, with subgroup analyses based on ovulatory status, oocyte origin, and cycle rank.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the evidence for T2D reversal using bariatric surgery, among other methods, and evaluate its advantages and limitations.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery has been recommended for T2D treatment since 2016 by an international diabetes consensus group, with evidence supporting its effectiveness in achieving T2D reversal. However, guidelines from ADA and EASD focus on treatment rather than reversal.
population_specificity: Patients with Type 2 diabetes (T2D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of nanotechnology-based drug delivery strategies to improve treatments for obesity and related comorbidities, including bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that bariatric surgery and pharmacotherapy for obesity often have adverse side effects and poor patient compliance, and it discusses nanotechnology as a promising alternative but does not provide specific results on bariatric surgery's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of obesity and related comorbidities).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of autophagy in obesity and evaluate the potential of DPP-4 inhibitors and GLP-1 receptor agonists as modulators of this process, rather than focusing on bariatric surgery itself.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that bariatric surgery's efficacy remains elusive due to weight regain within 5 years, and it highlights autophagy as a potential therapeutic target for obesity-related vascular complications, with GLP-1-based approaches showing promise in improving endothelial dysfunction.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract discusses obesity and metabolic disorders broadly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of oral supplementation with probiotics or synbiotics on body weight, BMI, and waist circumference in overweight and obese adults, excluding bariatric surgery or fecal transplantation.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of probiotics or synbiotics on body weight or BMI but noted a small reduction in waist circumference, though the quality of evidence was low to moderate. The authors concluded that current evidence is not definitive and called for large-scale trials.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults (BMI ≥ 25 kg/m²)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare end-of-trial health outcomes, including weight loss and diabetes remission, between participants who underwent bariatric surgery and those who received intensive lifestyle intervention or diabetes support and education.
results_summary: Surgically treated participants lost significantly more weight (19.3% of baseline weight) compared to the ILI (5.8%) and DSE (3.3%) groups and were more likely to achieve partial or full diabetes remission. The improvements were large and sustained, consistent with prior randomized trials.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes and overweight/obesity (BMI ≥ 30 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of bariatric surgery in treating metabolic complications of obesity, particularly type 2 diabetes, and to explore the mechanisms behind these effects.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is highly effective in improving or inducing remission of type 2 diabetes, with evidence supporting its superiority over intensive pharmacological treatment. The paper also discusses the mechanisms behind these outcomes and the updated consensus on bariatric surgery's role in diabetes treatment.
population_specificity: Individuals with higher degrees of obesity and metabolic complications, particularly type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The study aimed to investigate the prevalence and impact of obesity on metabolic control in patients with type 2 diabetes, excluding those who had undergone bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study did not evaluate bariatric surgery but found that obesity is a major determinant of poor metabolic control in type 2 diabetes patients, with significant associations between high BMI and poor outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes under follow-up in 69 tertiary healthcare units in 37 cities in Turkey, excluding those with bariatric surgery, pregnancy, or other specified conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the benefits of using a robotic camera assistant (SoloAssist®) in bariatric surgery compared to human assistance.
results_summary: The study found that robotic assistance was preferred by surgeons due to a steady image and self-control capabilities, though it was aborted in 18 of 331 procedures due to technical challenges in narrow spaces. Technical failures included short circuits, joystick failures, and control unit malfunctions.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric procedures (Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, laparoscopic gastric banding, sleeve gastrectomy, and gastroplication).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review potential mechanisms underlying the success of bariatric surgery in treating obesity and its comorbidities, focusing on endocrine, neural, and circulatory factors.
results_summary: The abstract highlights bariatric surgery as the most effective strategy for obesity treatment but notes incomplete understanding of its mechanisms. It suggests that elucidating these mechanisms could improve alternative treatments for obesity.
population_specificity: Obese patients and those with obesity-related comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a low-calorie diet (LCD) and omega-3 fatty acids on liver volume, visceral fat, and muscle area in morbidly obese women before bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Both LCD and omega-3 diets significantly reduced liver volume and visceral fat, but LCD had a greater effect on liver volume reduction. However, LCD also caused significant muscle loss and worse compliance due to more side effects, while omega-3 offered a safer, patient-friendly alternative.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese women undergoing laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery (LRYGB).
effective_dosage: LCD (800 kcal/day for 2 weeks) vs. omega-3 (2 g/day with a normal 2000 kcal/day diet for 4 weeks).
study_duration: 2 weeks for LCD, 4 weeks for omega-3.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare complications and healthcare resource utilization after bariatric surgery with or without continuous deep neuromuscular block (NMB) or opioid-free anaesthesia (OFA).
results_summary: OFA and continuous deep NMB were associated with fewer complications and lower healthcare resource utilization. Reduced hospital length of stay was linked to younger age, surgical team experience, and surgery type, but not continuous deep NMB.
population_specificity: 9,246 patients who underwent laparoscopic bariatric surgery from January 2009 to February 2017.
effective_dosage: Continuous deep NMB defined as rocuronium >1 mg/kg IBW/hour or sugammadex >2 mg/kg total body weight at reversal.
study_duration: Follow-up for complications and healthcare utilization up to 1 month post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether bariatric surgery changes patient salivary flow.
results_summary: The study found no significant alteration in salivary flow rate for up to 24 months after bariatric surgery, with five studies showing no difference, two showing increased flow, and one showing reduced flow.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery for morbid obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the food consumption patterns of severely obese patients (comparing men and women) candidates for bariatric surgery and identify promoting and protecting factors of obesity.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in food consumption patterns between men and women with severe obesity. Protective factors (e.g., fiber, vegetables, fruits) positively correlated with healthier patterns, while promoting factors (e.g., fats, saturated fats, soft drinks, fast food) negatively correlated. Caloric consumption was the component most strongly correlated with the pattern.
population_specificity: Severely obese patients (men and women) candidates for bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of fibroblast growth factor 19 (FGF19) in the metabolic benefits of bariatric surgery and explore its potential as a non-surgical treatment for diabetes and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).
results_summary: Bariatric surgery rapidly induced FGF19 in rodents and humans, contributing to diabetes remission independent of weight loss. While an FGF19 analog (NGM282) did not improve hyperglycemia in type 2 diabetes patients, it significantly reduced liver fat and improved histology in NASH patients, replicating a key benefit of bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Severely obese patients with diabetes (human and rodent models) and patients with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety outcomes of one anastomosis gastric bypass (OAGB) versus standard Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) in treating morbid obesity.
results_summary: OAGB was found to be non-inferior to RYGB in terms of weight loss and metabolic improvement at 2 years, but it had higher incidences of diarrhea, steatorrhea, and nutritional adverse events, suggesting a malabsorptive effect.
population_specificity: Patients with a body-mass index (BMI) of 40 kg/m² or higher from nine obesity centers in France.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the most common elements of Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) protocols for intra-abdominal procedures, including bariatric surgery, to identify best practices and generalizable outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that ERAS protocols, when implemented by a multidisciplinary team, optimize perioperative care for intra-abdominal surgeries, including bariatric procedures, by breaking traditional silos and coordinating interventions. The most effective and generalizable elements of ERAS protocols were highlighted, though applicability varies by procedure and patient.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing intra-abdominal surgical procedures, including bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term prevalence of mental disorders after bariatric surgery and their relationship with weight changes and health-related quality of life.
results_summary: The study found that mental disorder prevalence decreased significantly at 4 and 5 years post-surgery but not at 7 years. Mood and anxiety disorders were linked to less improvement in mental health-related quality of life, independent of weight change, while mood disorders showed a non-significant association with weight regain.
population_specificity: 199 adults from three U.S. academic medical centers who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term weight loss effects and safety profiles of laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy and laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB) in treating morbid obesity.
results_summary: LRYGB showed significantly greater percent excess weight loss at 3 and 5 years compared to sleeve gastrectomy, but had a higher incidence of total complications. No significant differences were found in type 2 diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, or sleep apnea between the two procedures.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the changes in gut bacteria following different types of bariatric surgery and their potential contribution to metabolic benefits.
results_summary: The study found increased microbial diversity and gene richness post-surgery, with specific changes in bacterial species abundance, such as decreased Faecalibacterium prausnitzii and increased Escherichia coli. The effects varied by surgery type, with Firmicutes decreasing after sleeve gastrectomy and Bacteroidetes and Proteobacteria increasing after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
population_specificity: 222 participants (146 Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, 25 sleeve gastrectomy, 30 biliointestinal bypass, 7 vertical banded gastroplasty, 14 adjustable gastric band).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery in improving quality of life and reducing cardiovascular risks in obese individuals.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery in people with BMI ≥ 40 or ≥ 35 with comorbidities can substantially affect quality of life and may reduce cardiovascular risks.
population_specificity: Individuals with BMI ≥ 40 or ≥ 35 with comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the benefits of bariatric surgery on all-cause mortality, cardiovascular disease, cancer, and diabetes control, particularly its weight-independent effects on glycemic improvement.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery showed significant benefits, including disease remission in type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and metabolic improvements beyond weight loss, leading to its inclusion in T2DM treatment algorithms. The procedure is now recommended for patients with class 1 obesity and T2DM, previously not indicated.
population_specificity: Patients with T2DM, including those with class 1 obesity (BMI 30-35 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current pharmacotherapy options for obesity and analyze clinical trials of new drug candidates, comparing their efficacy and limitations to bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results on bariatric surgery but highlights that pharmacotherapy options often result in minimal weight loss (<4 kg) and significant adverse effects, with new drug candidates showing no substantial improvement.
population_specificity: Not specified (general obese population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term effects of bariatric surgery on anxiety and depressive symptom severity in morbidly obese patients.
results_summary: The study found significant long-term reductions in depressive and anxiety symptoms 2-3 years after bariatric surgery, though pre-operative scores did not predict post-operative BMI outcomes, and weight loss did not predict changes in anxiety symptoms.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients with a BMI ≥ 35 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between loss of control eating (LOCE), binge eating disorder (BED), and weight loss outcomes after bariatric surgery, as well as predictors of postoperative LOCE.
results_summary: LOCE and BED initially declined post-surgery but later increased, with new cases emerging. LOCE was associated with less concurrent weight loss but not prospective or cumulative weight loss. Factors like self-monitoring, higher eating frequency, older age, male gender, and higher self-esteem reduced the likelihood of LOCE.
population_specificity: 2156 patients who underwent laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding (LAGB) or Roux-n-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) in the LABS-2 study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical outcomes of concomitant cholecystectomy during four types of bariatric surgery versus bariatric surgery alone.
results_summary: The study found a higher rate of anastomotic leak/stricture with concomitant cholecystectomy during gastric bypass compared to gastric bypass alone. Data on other bariatric procedures were insufficient to quantify outcome differences.
population_specificity: 13,675 patients undergoing bariatric surgery, with some receiving concomitant cholecystectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of bariatric surgery as a preventive measure against pancreatic cancer by reducing obesity-related risks.
results_summary: The study suggests that bariatric surgery, combined with healthy lifestyle habits, can reduce the chances of pancreatic cancer in extremely obese patients by promoting weight loss and mitigating obesity-related mechanisms like inflammation and hormonal imbalance.
population_specificity: Extremely obese patients at risk for pancreatic cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of knotless barbed sutures compared to conventional sutures in bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that knotless barbed sutures significantly reduced suture time and operative time compared to conventional sutures. Subgroup analysis of RCTs indicated fewer bleeding conditions in the barbed suture group, though no significant changes were observed in overall postoperative complications or hospital stay.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine psychiatric predictors of body image dissatisfaction (BID) in bariatric surgery candidates, focusing on early trauma and attachment style.
results_summary: Binge eating behavior, depression severity, female gender, and insecure attachment style were significant predictors of BID, while early trauma and BMI were not associated with BID. The study highlighted the role of insecure attachment style in BID, suggesting implications for pre- and post-operative interventions.
population_specificity: 536 patients with extreme obesity (mean BMI=43 kg/m²) undergoing presurgical psychiatric evaluations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of bariatric surgery in managing obesity-related atrial fibrillation (AF) and its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that bariatric surgery is discussed as a treatment strategy for obesity-related AF, but specific efficacy results are not detailed. The focus is on the broader relationship between obesity, AF, and potential interventions.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity (BMI ≥30 kg/m²) and associated atrial fibrillation.

study_goal: To review current strategies for treating hypertension associated with pediatric obesity, including the role of bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract mentions bariatric surgery as a rare treatment option for obesity-related hypertension in children, but no specific results or outcomes related to its efficacy are provided.
population_specificity: Pediatric and adolescent populations with obesity and hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an expert consensus on standardizing baseline patient data collections in specialist obesity management clinics, including considerations for bariatric surgery referrals.
results_summary: The study achieved consensus on a recommended set of core and useful baseline data items for obesity management services, with specific considerations for bariatric surgery patients, to facilitate clinical audits and research collaborations.
population_specificity: Specialist obesity management clinics in Australia, including patients referred for bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the frequency of histologically proven bile reflux and postoperative complications between one anastomosis gastric bypass (OAGB) and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) in patients with morbid obesity.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in bile reflux frequency, bile reflux index, Sydney system score, or postoperative complications between OAGB and RYGB groups, suggesting both techniques are equally effective and safe.
population_specificity: 122 obese patients (22 males) who underwent RYGB or OAGB surgery, excluding those with revisional surgery.

study_goal: To determine the durability of improvements in sexual functioning after bariatric surgery and identify factors associated with these improvements.
results_summary: Approximately half of women and men who were dissatisfied with their sexual life before surgery experienced sustained improvements in satisfaction over 5 years. Greater postsurgical reduction in depressive symptoms was independently associated with improvements in sexual functioning domains, while surgical procedure type was not.
population_specificity: Adults undergoing their first bariatric procedure (78.9% women, median age 47 years, median BMI 45.8).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare changes in beta-cell function between sleeve gastrectomy (SG) and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) in obese patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) after similar weight loss.
results_summary: Both SG and RYGB showed significant short-term improvements in beta-cell function, with no significant difference between the two procedures. Weight loss, fasting glucose, acute insulin secretion, and insulin sensitivity were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Obese patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the incidence of clinically significant bone mineral density (BMD) loss at 6 and 12 months after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: A clinically significant reduction in BMD was observed in 62.1% of patients at 6 months and 71.6% at 12 months post-surgery, strongly associated with weight loss. No osteoporosis cases were reported, but there were four cases of osteopenia and one fracture.
population_specificity: 110 patients treated for severe obesity at a specialized center in France.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the characteristics of obesity, its relation to morbidities, and its management in South Asians, including the need for aggressive interventions like diet and exercise.
results_summary: The study found that South Asians exhibit a unique obesity phenotype with higher body fat and lower muscle mass at similar BMIs, increasing risks for type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease. It highlighted challenges in obesity management, such as lack of awareness, cultural barriers, and insufficient healthcare resources, advocating for early and intensive interventions.
population_specificity: South Asians

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether weight loss, including through bariatric surgery, reduces the severity and incidence of psoriasis or psoriatic arthritis in obese individuals.
results_summary: Two cohort studies suggested that bariatric surgery, particularly gastric bypass, reduces the risk of developing psoriasis (hazard ratio 0·52). No RCTs of bariatric surgery were identified, limiting definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Obese individuals with or at risk of psoriasis or psoriatic arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of IV acetaminophen compared to placebo for pain management after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: IV acetaminophen significantly reduced postoperative pain scores and opioid use 24 hours after surgery but did not affect the length of hospital stay. The meta-analysis included four RCTs with consistent findings supporting its efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery as a weight loss intervention for improving obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and related metabolic conditions.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery, along with other weight loss interventions, significantly improves OSA, with greater weight loss leading to remission. It also reduces cardiovascular risk by ameliorating obesity-related metabolic conditions.
population_specificity: Obese individuals with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the intraoperative performance, postoperative results, and clinical outcomes of two laparoscopic devices (Harmonic® scalpel and LigaSure™) in patients undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in operative time, intraoperative complications, or postoperative complications between the two devices. Both devices were deemed user-friendly and effective, with the choice between them depending on surgeon preference and hospital cost policies.
population_specificity: 422 morbidly obese patients undergoing LSG at a single bariatric unit in Italy between 2009 and 2017.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of bariatric surgery on oral levothyroxine absorption and postoperative thyroid function.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery may both impair levothyroxine absorption due to altered gastric conditions and reduce dose requirements due to weight loss and changes in thyroid hormone homeostasis. Close monitoring of thyroid function post-surgery is advised.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity undergoing bariatric surgery, particularly those on levothyroxine therapy for hypothyroidism.
interactions: Levothyroxine absorption may be affected by changes in gastric pH and volume post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of bariatric surgery on the prevalence of pelvic floor dysfunctions (urinary incontinence, pelvic organ prolapse, and fecal incontinence) in women with morbid obesity.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery significantly reduced urinary incontinence in obese women, but its effects on fecal incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse were less clear. The analysis included 20 studies with 3,684 patients, showing a mean BMI reduction of 12.90 kg/m² post-surgery.
population_specificity: Women with morbid obesity undergoing bariatric surgery in multiple academic and private centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the nephroprotective effects and renal outcomes of bariatric surgery in patients with morbid obesity, particularly its impact on conditions like insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, diabetes mellitus, and arterial hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery leads to significant and persistent weight loss, correction of comorbid conditions, and positive renal outcomes such as reduced albuminuria/proteinuria, improved or stabilized glomerular filtration rate, and delayed end-stage renal failure. However, further research is needed to assess long-term renal consequences and risks like acute kidney damage, nephrolithiasis, and nephrocalcinosis.
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity, including those with pre-existing renal impairment or on dialysis.

study_goal: To review the effects of bariatric surgery on endometrial cancer risk reduction and its potential as an adjunct treatment.
results_summary: The study found ample evidence that bariatric surgery reduces endometrial cancer risk in obese women (BMI >30 kg/m²) and explored its impact on endometrial pathology, metabolic profiles, and potential adjunctive treatment roles.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese individuals (BMI >30 kg/m²), particularly women at risk for or with endometrial cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of endoluminal revision techniques for managing weight regain after gastric bypass surgery.
results_summary: The study reviewed various endoscopic revision approaches, noting their procedural safety and efficacy in addressing weight regain, and suggested that endoscopic revision may become the gold standard for this purpose.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent gastric bypass surgery and experienced weight regain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess ethnic disparities in diabetic metabolic outcomes following bariatric surgery, focusing on weight loss and glucose metabolism normalization.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in BMI, weight, fasting insulin, glucose, and HbA1c across all ethnic groups by 6 months, with most patients achieving diabetes remission by 12 months, though Asian and Black patients showed less sustained improvement.
population_specificity: 650 patients with type II diabetes mellitus (T2DM) from a single academic institution in northern California, including Non-Hispanic, Hispanic, Black, and Asian ethnicities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and clinical application of obesity pharmacotherapy in youth with obesity, including gaps in treatment options like bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract highlights a treatment gap for youth with severe obesity, where bariatric surgery is an effective option but pharmacotherapy remains underutilized. It notes the presence of obesity-related comorbidities and the limited pharmacotherapy options for youth compared to adults.
population_specificity: Youth (adolescents) with severe obesity and related comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining bariatric surgery (laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding) with lifestyle interventions leads to significant additional weight reduction compared to lifestyle interventions alone in severely obese adolescents, and to assess its effect on obesity-associated co-morbidities.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery in adolescents shows substantial weight loss and health improvement, similar to outcomes seen in adults, though well-designed prospective studies in this age group are rare. The trial is designed to provide important safety and efficacy data for gastric banding in adolescents with unsuccessful lifestyle interventions.
population_specificity: Severely obese adolescents aged 14-16 years with a sex- and age-adjusted BMI >40 kg/m² or >35 kg/m² with obesity-related co-morbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of metabolic (bariatric) surgery to ameliorate, resolve, or cure type 2 diabetes, including future procedures not focused on weight loss.
results_summary: The study suggests that metabolic surgery can improve or resolve type 2 diabetes, with future procedures likely targeting neurohormonal modulation. It emphasizes that metabolic surgery is evolving, with no permanent gold standard, and highlights its role in both clinical practice and basic research.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of metabolic surgery for type 2 diabetes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the role of bariatric surgery as an underutilized tool for weight management and metabolic syndrome control in liver transplant recipients to reduce cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.
results_summary: The abstract suggests bariatric surgery is underutilized in liver transplant recipients and emphasizes its potential role in managing metabolic syndrome and weight, which are critical for cardiovascular disease prevention post-transplant. No specific outcomes or data on bariatric surgery's effects are provided.
population_specificity: Liver transplant recipients with a focus on those at risk for cardiovascular disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the incidence and risk factors of trocar site hernias following laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that trocar site hernias are an underestimated complication, with a pooled incidence of 3.22% (range 0-39.3%). Higher BMI and systematic hernia detection using imaging were associated with significantly higher incidence rates.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of bariatric surgery on 24-hour blood pressure profile, BP variability, and resistant hypertension prevalence in obese patients.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery (Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass combined with medical therapy) significantly improved 24-hour BP profile and variability compared to medical therapy alone, and reduced the prevalence of resistant hypertension.
population_specificity: Obese patients with grade 1 and 2 hypertension using at least 2 antihypertensive drugs at maximal doses or >2 at moderate doses (76% female, BMI 36.9±2.7 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review surgical options for abdominal body contouring in patients with diverse clinical histories, including those who underwent bariatric surgery, and provide an evidence-based treatment algorithm.
results_summary: The study highlights the increased demand for body contouring procedures post-bariatric surgery and emphasizes the need for individualized approaches to achieve safe, realistic, and long-lasting aesthetic outcomes. It reviews surgical options but does not provide specific efficacy or safety data for bariatric surgery itself.
population_specificity: Patients with abdominal contour deformities, including those who underwent bariatric surgery, weight loss, previous pregnancy, or aging.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors contributing to preoperative weight loss and assess their influence on short-term outcomes of bariatric surgery under the ERAS protocol.
results_summary: Diabetes mellitus, obstructive sleep apnea, and previous surgery predicted preoperative weight loss, while steatohepatitis and respiratory disorders reduced it. Preoperative weight loss did not affect early outcomes except operative time but improved postoperative weight loss and follow-up participation.
population_specificity: 909 bariatric patients treated under ERAS principles in two bariatric centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of bariatric surgery in elderly patients (65 years and older) over a 3-year period.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery resulted in significant weight loss (mean EBW loss of 70.76%) and improvement or remission of comorbidities in most patients, with a low rate of perioperative complications (8.86%) and no reported deaths.
population_specificity: Elderly patients aged 65 and older (mean age 67.92) with obesity (mean BMI 40.32 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence on weight loss interventions, including bariatric surgery, for obesity in adults aged over 60 years.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery showed comparable weight loss and type 2 diabetes resolution in older adults, with similar or slightly higher complication rates compared to younger individuals. Older age alone should not contraindicate surgical intervention.
population_specificity: Adults aged over 60 years with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of probiotic supplements on blood markers of endotoxin, inflammation, and lipid peroxidation in morbidly obese patients undergoing one-anastomosis gastric bypass (OAGB).
results_summary: Probiotic supplementation for 4 months improved serum LBP, TNF-α, and vitamin D3 levels and aided weight loss, but these effects did not persist 9 months after treatment cessation.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients undergoing OAGB surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effects of the duodenal-jejunal bypass liner (DJBL) on weight loss and glycemic control in patients.
results_summary: The study found that the initial weight reduction effect of DJBL treatment diminished after 4 years, with no statistically significant difference in median weight or BMI compared to baseline. Five patients underwent additional bariatric surgery, suggesting limited long-term efficacy of DJBL alone.
population_specificity: 29 patients treated with DJBL at two centers, with 15 eligible for follow-up.
study_duration: Median follow-up of 42 months after DJBL removal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review weight loss interventions, including bariatric surgery, in the context of precision medicine, focusing on sustainability and real-world application.
results_summary: The abstract highlights bariatric surgery as one of the interventions reviewed for weight loss, emphasizing its role alongside genetic, epigenetic, pharmacological, and lifestyle factors, but does not provide specific results for bariatric surgery alone.
population_specificity: Obese individuals, particularly Americans attempting weight loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an open-lung approach with protective ventilation strategy (PEEP of 10 cm H2O) reduces postoperative hypoxemia in obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery (LBS).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the incidence of postoperative hypoxemia between the control group (PEEP 5 cm H2O) and the intervention group (PEEP 10 cm H2O). The protective ventilation strategy did not reduce hypoxemia in obese patients undergoing LBS.
population_specificity: Obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Tidal volume 8 mL/kg of ideal body weight, PEEP levels of 5 cm H2O (control) and 10 cm H2O (intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of bariatric surgery on the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, fertility, ovarian reserve, and contraception efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery can reverse the adverse effects of obesity on fertility and positively impact the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis and ovarian reserve. It also addressed contraception efficacy post-surgery.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity, particularly focusing on fertility-related outcomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare postoperative pain, nausea/vomiting, and other outcomes between patients undergoing Roux-en-Y gastric bypass with an ERAS protocol versus a standard care protocol.
results_summary: The ERAS protocol resulted in significantly lower postoperative pain, reduced nausea/vomiting, shorter hospital stays, and lower acute phase reactant levels compared to standard care, with no significant differences in complications, mortality, or readmission rates.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing Roux-en-Y gastric bypass at a university hospital in Spain.
study_duration: Postoperative outcomes were evaluated 24 hours after surgery, with hospital stay duration noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of gut microbiota modification, including bariatric surgery, on host metabolism and its potential role in treating type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and obesity.
results_summary: The study suggests that bariatric surgery, among other interventions, can alter gut microbiota composition, leading to beneficial metabolic effects such as reduced inflammation, improved glucose levels, and increased GLP-1 secretion, which may help manage T2DM and obesity.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of gut microbiota and metabolic conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the long-term (23-year) effects of gastric banding (LAGB) on mortality and incidence of obesity-related co-morbidities compared to medical weight loss therapy.
results_summary: LAGB was associated with significantly reduced mortality, lower incidence of diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, cancer, renal diseases, and fewer hospital admissions compared to medical therapy. The preventive effects on co-morbidities and hospital admissions increased over time, though mortality reduction efficacy slightly decreased compared to shorter-term studies.
population_specificity: Obese patients with a BMI > 35 kg/m², including those with and without diabetes.
study_duration: Final observation period was 19.5 ± 1.87 years (range: 13.4-23.5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the literature on challenges before and during pregnancy after bariatric surgery, including fertility, nutritional deficiencies, and pregnancy outcomes.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery improves obesity-related pregnancy complications like gestational diabetes and hypertension but introduces new risks such as nutritional deficiencies, anemia, and small for gestational age offspring. The study highlights the lack of consensus on the ideal time to conceive post-surgery.
population_specificity: Women of childbearing age who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness, risk profiles, and metabolic impact of bariatric surgery for obesity and related disorders, as well as barriers to its utilization.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is highly effective for weight loss and improving metabolic disorders like diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and fatty liver disease, but also highlighted the need to consider risks and operative choices. Reoperative surgery and access challenges were also discussed.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity and related metabolic disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current status of surgical options, including bariatric surgery, for treating Type 1 diabetes.
results_summary: The abstract highlights bariatric surgery as a successful treatment for Type 2 diabetes and obesity but notes its use in Type 1 diabetes remains unestablished and controversial. Recent advances in surgical interventions and technology may expand treatment options for Type 1 diabetes.
population_specificity: Individuals with Type 1 diabetes and obesity (though primarily discussed in the context of Type 2 diabetes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether multi-frequency bioelectric impedance (MF-BI) is a valid tool for assessing body composition in obese patients following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The review found that MF-BI is reliable for group-level assessments, and obese-specific algorithm adjustments improve accuracy. However, inconsistencies among studies highlight the need for more robust research to establish clear validity.
population_specificity: Obese patients (BMI ≥ 30 kg/m²) who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify early markers of cardiac dysfunction in obesity and understand the underlying pathophysiology to improve risk stratification, monitoring, and treatment strategies for obesity patients.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, with analyses currently being performed; it is expected to provide insights into early cardiac dysfunction markers and their pathophysiology in obesity patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Obesity patients with a BMI ≥35 kg/m² scheduled for bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of bariatric surgery in weight loss and cardiovascular health, alongside other preventive and treatment modalities for obesity.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on bariatric surgery but mentions it as one of the considerations beyond lifestyle changes for weight loss.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on obesity and cardiovascular risks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine changes in intestinal microbiota after bariatric surgery and the impact of probiotics on this population.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery altered intestinal microbiota, increasing Bacteroidetes and Proteobacteria while reducing Firmicutes. Probiotics reduced gastrointestinal symptoms, enhanced vitamin B12 synthesis, and potentially amplified weight loss.
population_specificity: Adults undergoing Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or sleeve vertical gastrectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery as a therapeutic option for managing NAFLD in morbidly obese individuals when lifestyle modifications and pharmacotherapy fail.
results_summary: The study suggests bariatric surgery should be considered for selected morbidly obese individuals with NAFLD when other treatments fail, though specific efficacy data are not detailed in the abstract. It highlights the lack of approved pharmacological interventions for NAFLD and positions bariatric surgery as a viable alternative.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese individuals with NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of bariatric surgery, particularly LSG, on gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) in morbidly obese patients.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery, especially RYGB, effectively reduces GERD symptoms and obesity-related complications, while LSG shows a higher risk of GERD post-surgery. LAGB initially improves symptoms but may lead to new reflux issues over time.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients with or at risk of GERD.

study_goal: To determine the influence of biliopancreatic limb length on weight loss and remission of co-morbidities in Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
results_summary: Weight loss was superior in longer biliopancreatic limbs, and the release of enterohormones in response to food in the distal small bowel appears to play a key role in co-morbidity remission.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of using cardiac septal defect occluders (CSDO) for treating post-bariatric surgery leaks, particularly in patients who failed previous endoscopic treatments.
results_summary: The study found that CSDO had a high clinical success rate (90.7%) for non-acute leaks, with all chronic, late, and early leaks successfully closed except one undrained late leak. Early leaks required a second placement of a larger CSDO for permanent closure, while acute leaks were not successfully treated.
population_specificity: Patients with post-bariatric surgical leaks (31 sleeve gastrectomy and 12 Roux-en-Y gastric bypass), divided into acute (n=3), early (n=5), late (n=23), and chronic (n=12) leaks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of bariatric surgery, particularly Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB), on taste perception and food selection preferences.
results_summary: The study found that RYGB is effective for weight loss and Type 2 diabetes treatment, but empirical support for changes in food preferences away from fats and sugars is mixed. The surgery may alter the taste and palatability of fats and sugars.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of RYGB patients and preclinical/clinical findings).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and review neurosurgery-related complications of bariatric surgery and present illustrative cases to highlight peri- and post-operative therapeutic precautions.
results_summary: The study identified three pathological mechanisms linked to bariatric surgery complications: intracranial pressure alterations, nutrient deficiencies leading to neuro- or myelo-encephalopathies, and dysregulation of autonomic/endocrine control. The authors emphasize the need for neurosurgeons to be aware of these multifactorial complications due to their likely increasing prevalence.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery, with a focus on neurosurgery-related complications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, clinical effectiveness, and cost-effectiveness of bariatric surgery, weight-management programmes, and orlistat pharmacotherapy for adults with severe obesity.
results_summary: Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) produced the greatest long-term weight change (-20.23 kg at 60 months) and was cost-effective compared to no surgery and weight-management programmes. However, the study noted limitations in generalizability and long-term follow-up for complications.
population_specificity: Adults with severe obesity (BMI ≥ 35 kg/m²).
study_duration: Long-term follow-up (up to 60 months for RYGB).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and analyze the long-term (≥5 years) outcomes of metabolic and bariatric surgery in adolescents with severe obesity, focusing on adiposity indicators, co-morbidity remission, and complications.
results_summary: The study found substantial reduction in body mass index (from 47 to 32.4 kg/m²) and high remission rates for co-morbidities (75-85%), but noted weight regain in some cases and high prevalence of iron deficiency and anemia (30-70% and 16-50%, respectively). Long-term complications were inadequately reported.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 10-20 years with severe obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to collate studies on bariatric surgery in Indigenous peoples and provide a framework for future research on this issue.
results_summary: Indigenous peoples had lower access to bariatric surgery, and one study found greater weight loss compared to non-Indigenous peoples. The review highlighted a lack of studies but noted emerging interest in the topic.
population_specificity: Indigenous peoples worldwide

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery as a treatment for the obese asthma phenotype.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery, along with exercise programs and weight loss, improved quality of life, symptoms, and exercise capacity in obese asthma patients, with reductions in medication use and exacerbations. It was identified as an effective treatment for this specific phenotype.
population_specificity: Obese patients with severe difficult-to-treat asthma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of IV ibuprofen and paracetamol on pain management and opioid consumption in patients undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG).
results_summary: IV ibuprofen resulted in lower pain scores and reduced opioid use compared to paracetamol and saline control in the first 24 hours post-LSG. Opioid consumption was significantly higher in the control group than in the ibuprofen or paracetamol groups.
population_specificity: 90 patients undergoing LSG at Istanbul Medipol University Hospital.
effective_dosage: 800 mg IV ibuprofen (Group I), 1000 mg IV paracetamol (Group P), 100 ml saline (Group C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of a 4-week very low-calorie diet (VLCD) on collagen deposition in wounds and liver volume in patients undergoing laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
results_summary: The study found that preoperative VLCD reduced liver volume and decreased expression of mature collagen in wounds post-surgery, but the clinical impact on anastomotic healing remains unclear. Secondary outcomes included liver fibrosis score, body composition, and surgical metrics, though detailed results were not fully provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (n=20, split into control and VLCD groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the epidemiology, pathophysiology, clinical features, and management of obesity-related kidney disease in children and adolescents.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Bariatric Surgery's effects, focusing instead on the broader context of obesity-related kidney disease.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with severe obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bariatric surgery improves mental health quality of life (QoL) compared to non-surgical interventions.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in mental health QoL from baseline with bariatric surgery compared to non-surgical treatments. Final mental health QoL scores were similar between surgical and non-surgical groups, with subgroup analyses also failing to identify a beneficial effect.
population_specificity: 731 participants from 11 randomized controlled trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare long-term mortality outcomes between obese patients who underwent malabsorptive bariatric surgery (BPD and BIBP) and those who received non-surgical medical treatment for obesity.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery patients had significantly lower all-cause, cardiovascular-related, and cancer-related mortality compared to non-surgical patients over a mean follow-up of 12.1 years. The mortality rates were 7.2% in the surgical group versus 12.9% in the non-surgical group.
population_specificity: Obese patients with a BMI > 35 kg/m² (n=1877).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an overview of the current status of endoscopic negative pressure therapy (ENPT) in the upper gastrointestinal tract, including its use for complications after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: ENPT has been used in over 400 patients with transmural defects in the upper gastrointestinal tract, achieving an 87% success rate. It is applied for complications after bariatric surgery, among other indications, with innovative techniques expanding its applications.
population_specificity: Patients with transmural defects in the upper gastrointestinal tract, including those with complications after bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between obesity and olfaction, and evaluate the impact of bariatric surgery on olfactory function.
results_summary: The study found that olfactory function is negatively correlated with body weight, and bariatric surgery, particularly sleeve gastrectomy, effectively reverses olfactory decline associated with obesity.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity, including those who underwent bariatric surgery (Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the risk of lithium toxicity following bariatric surgery and propose solutions for managing lithium treatment in such patients.
results_summary: The study reported a case of lithium toxicity, including severe bradycardia requiring a permanent pacemaker, after sleeve gastrectomy. It highlights the need for awareness and monitoring of lithium absorption changes post-bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: A 61-year-old male patient who underwent sleeve gastrectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the incidence of comorbidities (diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, and cancer) in obese patients undergoing malabsorptive bariatric surgeries (BPD and BIBP) versus standard medical treatment.
