results_summary: Malabsorptive surgeries significantly reduced new cases of diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, hyperlipidemia, oculopathy, and cancer compared to non-surgical controls. The preventive effects were more pronounced in nondiabetic subjects for coronary heart disease and cancer.
population_specificity: 1983 obese patients with BMI >35 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate the BODY-Q, a patient-reported outcome measure (PROM) for assessing outcomes in weight loss and/or body contouring surgery.
results_summary: The study developed the BODY-Q through literature review, patient and cognitive interviews, and expert input, resulting in a conceptual framework covering appearance concerns, health-related quality of life, and experience of care. Multiple independently functioning scales were created for each domain.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing weight loss and/or body contouring surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of bariatric surgery on weight loss and obesity-related comorbidities.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery contributes to significant weight loss and a notable reduction in weight-related comorbidities such as type 2 diabetes, hypertension, heart disease, and obstructive sleep apnea.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity in the United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the safety and efficacy of endoscopic bariatric and metabolic therapies (EBMTs) compared to traditional bariatric surgery, as well as the role of endoscopic revision after failed surgical intervention.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that bariatric surgery is effective for sustained weight loss and metabolic syndrome improvement, but access is limited. EBMTs are designed to mimic surgical effects, with ongoing evaluation of their safety and efficacy. Endoscopic revision after failed surgery is also discussed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of EBMTs and bariatric surgery)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery in managing PCOS symptoms, particularly in cases of morbid obesity unresponsive to lifestyle and medical treatments.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery can lead to significant weight loss (25% to 50%), which may be necessary for morbid obesity in PCOS patients unresponsive to other treatments, improving metabolic and reproductive outcomes.
population_specificity: Women with PCOS, particularly those with morbid obesity (BMI ≥40 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term effectiveness of bariatric surgery versus lifestyle intervention for Class I obesity patients.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery resulted in significantly higher excess weight loss percentages at 1, 3, 5, 7, and 10 years compared to lifestyle intervention. The study concluded that bariatric surgery, particularly laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy, is more effective for Class I obesity patients.
population_specificity: Patients with Class I obesity (BMI 30-35 kg/m²) and follow-up >7 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize existing knowledge on why bariatric surgery remains underused in the U.S., focusing on health insurance benefits and design, and to discuss the applicability of value-based insurance design to bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is cost-effective compared to nonsurgical treatments for individuals with extreme obesity and type 2 diabetes, with potential long-term cost stability or reduction. However, barriers like limited patient and physician knowledge, as well as insurance coverage issues, contribute to its underuse.
population_specificity: Individuals with extreme obesity and type 2 diabetes eligible for bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether incorporating eHealth applications as part of standard postoperative care could enhance clinical outcomes such as weight loss and comorbidity reduction in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The study evaluated the value of different levels of eHealth in postoperative care but did not report specific outcomes regarding bariatric surgery's effects in the abstract. The trial addresses the potential benefits of eHealth in a changing healthcare environment.
population_specificity: Adult patients with a BMI ≥ 40 kg/m² or ≥ 35 kg/m² with obesity-related comorbidities undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: To examine the effects of bariatric surgery on nocturnal hypoxemia in obese patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: Bariatric surgery improved nocturnal hypoxemia (MeanSaO₂ increased) and reduced body weight and apnea events in obese patients with OSA. The findings suggest efficacy, but more randomized controlled trials are needed for confirmation.
population_specificity: Obese patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) surgery on the pharmacokinetics of amoxicillin in obese subjects.
results_summary: The study found that RYGB surgery significantly increased systemic exposure to amoxicillin in obese subjects, though levels remained lower than those reported in non-obese volunteers. Weight loss and BMI reduction were also observed post-surgery.
population_specificity: Obese subjects (n=8) undergoing RYGB surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term effectiveness of bariatric surgery versus medical management in inducing remission of type 2 diabetes (T2D) in obese patients.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery showed significantly higher T2D remission rates (52.5% at 2 years, 27.5% at 5 years) compared to medical management (3.5% at 2 years, 3.8% at 5 years). Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) also demonstrated superior glycemic control and improved lipid profiles.
population_specificity: Obese patients with type 2 diabetes and BMI > 25 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate lidocaine serum concentrations and safety in obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery when administered based on adjusted body weight.
results_summary: The study found that lidocaine administration based on adjusted body weight resulted in serum concentrations within the accepted range (1.5-5 µg·mL), with no reported toxicity or adverse events. The protocol included a bolus followed by a continuous infusion, adjusted post-surgery until discharge.
population_specificity: 42 obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: 1.5 mg·kg bolus IV, followed by 2 mg·kg·hour infusion, then reduced to 1 mg·kg·hour post-surgery.
study_duration: Until discharge from the recovery room.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an evidence-based summary of nutrition-related practices in bariatric surgery and assess the role of registered dietitian nutritionists in postoperative outcomes.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly reduces resting metabolic rate and postoperative energy intake, but macronutrient distribution does not significantly affect weight loss. Limited evidence suggests dietitian involvement improves weight loss outcomes, but further research is needed on behavior change.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing bariatric surgery (studies published from 2003 to 2015).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of follistatin (FST) and follistatin-like 3 (FSTL3) in glucose regulation and their response to bariatric surgery in morbidly obese individuals with or without type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that circulating FST and FSTL3 levels decreased after bariatric surgery (RYGB and sleeve gastrectomy), correlating with improved glucose homeostasis and insulin sensitivity. Changes in FST levels post-surgery were predictive of further improvements in glucose metrics at 6 months.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals (n=32) and morbidly obese individuals with or without type 2 diabetes (n=41).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the molecular mechanisms of antidiabetic drugs in managing diabesity and their impact on outcomes, emphasizing the importance of rational drug use alongside bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that bariatric surgery is the best treatment for diabesity but notes that many patients rely on antidiabetic drugs, which can variably affect outcomes due to their metabolic effects. It underscores the need for understanding drug mechanisms to optimize long-term diabesity management.
population_specificity: Patients with diabesity (diabetes related to obesity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate the efficacy of laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) on hypertension among obese patients.
results_summary: The study found that LSG is an effective intervention for reducing hypertension in bariatric patients, with potential additional health system benefits such as cost savings from reduced antihypertensive medication usage. The review included 14 studies with 3550 subjects, showing positive long-term outcomes.
population_specificity: Obese adult patients with hypertension undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether physical exercise contributes to weight loss or physical function improvement in adults receiving bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that physical exercise after bariatric surgery resulted in an additional 1.94 kg weight loss and a 29.67 m increase in 6-minute walk distance compared to surgery alone. Subgroup analyses indicated greater weight loss when exercise started one year or more post-surgery and when combining aerobic and resistance training.
population_specificity: Adults with obesity who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare concepts of appetite hormonal regulation, reasons for obesity development, and the effectiveness of bariatric procedures over the last decade.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgeries like Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, sleeve gastrectomy, and adjustable gastric banding effectively reduce body weight and improve metabolic syndrome components, though not all. Long-term hormonal profile changes post-surgery require further observation.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity and associated endocrine disturbances.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if patient attrition from bariatric surgery programs impacts clinical outcomes, specifically weight loss and metabolic comorbidity improvements.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant differences in weight loss outcomes between patients followed by the bariatric surgery practice (BSP) and those seen by other providers (ABSP) at 1 and 2 years post-surgery, with BSP patients showing higher total weight loss. Significant improvements in type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia were observed across all patients.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB) between 2008 and 2015 (N=1242).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the connection between bipolar disorder (BD) and obesity, and evaluate the role of bariatric surgery as a weight-loss intervention for patients with stable BD.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery may be the most robust intervention for weight loss in patients with stable BD, though access to it may be limited. Obesity in BD patients serves as a severity proxy and predictor of poorer outcomes, with obesity-related conditions contributing to premature mortality.
population_specificity: Patients with bipolar disorder (BD) who are at increased risk for obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe shared values, feelings, and thoughts among visitors to a web-based forum for those undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study identified four themes related to the bariatric surgery journey, including high and often unrealistic expectations, challenges in navigating the healthcare system, managing pre-operative diets, and dealing with others' attitudes. Posters viewed the surgery as a transformative but challenging process.
population_specificity: Visitors to a web-based forum for individuals undergoing bariatric surgery (498 posts analyzed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the per-patient procedural costs of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB), sleeve gastrectomy (SG), and adjustable gastric banding (AGB) in the UK.
results_summary: Mean procedural costs were £5002 for RYGB, £4306 for SG, and £2527 for AGB. Sensitivity analyses showed that varying staff seniority, procedure times, or consumable prices had modest impacts on costs (±4-13%), while adjusted total costs were similar to NHS tariffs for RYGB and SG but much lower for AGB.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery in two NHS hospitals and one private hospital in the UK.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of bariatric surgery as a therapeutic intervention for obesity in older adults, alongside other approaches.
results_summary: The abstract mentions bariatric surgery as a promising future intervention but notes insufficient evidence specific to obese older adults to recommend it at this time. Few studies focus on this population.
population_specificity: Older adults with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the incidence of alcohol use disorder (AUD) following sleeve gastrectomy (SG) and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found that AUD prevalence increased postoperatively, particularly after the second year, with similar rates between SG and RYGB. Higher educational level and household income were identified as predisposing factors for AUD development.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery (n=5724).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the evidence on the use of telemedicine for providing healthcare services to bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The review found that telemedicine may be a potential method for delivering healthcare services to bariatric surgery patients, with studies examining its feasibility, acceptance, and impact on weight loss and behavioral changes. However, the evidence base was insufficient for definitive conclusions, with only one randomized controlled trial showing significant differences between intervention and control groups.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bariatric surgery (Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy) leads to changes in common bile duct diameter and whether the type of surgery affects biliary pathophysiology.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery results in common bile duct dilation, with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass causing a greater increase (1.4 mm) compared to sleeve gastrectomy (0.5 mm). The dilation occurred regardless of cholecystectomy status.
population_specificity: Adult patients who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy between January 2010 and December 2013, with pre- and post-operative imaging studies.
study_duration: Average follow-up time was 24.1 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association of bariatric surgery with suicide events and suicide/self-harm attempts in patients who underwent weight loss surgery.
results_summary: The study found that post-bariatric surgery patients had a suicide event rate of 2.7/1000 patients and a suicide/self-harm attempt rate of 17/1000 patients, with higher risks compared to pre-surgery and matched controls (OR 1.9 and 3.8, respectively).
population_specificity: Predominantly female (76.9%) patients who underwent bariatric surgery, with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) as the most common procedure (58.9%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of bariatric/metabolic surgery versus various drugs in achieving weight reduction and glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that bariatric/metabolic surgery is a viable treatment for weight loss and glycemic control in type 2 diabetes patients, though it does not provide specific comparative results. Lifestyle changes alone are noted as insufficient, prompting the exploration of surgical and pharmaceutical interventions.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes and obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review endoscopic approaches for managing biliary stones in patients with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery.
results_summary: The study found that Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is effective for weight loss but can lead to biliary stones, making endoscopic removal challenging. It highlights various endoscopic techniques and provides a treatment algorithm for such cases.
population_specificity: Patients with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass reconstruction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative weight loss improves clinical outcomes in surgical patients with clinically significant obesity, particularly focusing on bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Preoperative weight loss programs led to significant weight reduction but were not associated with reduced perioperative mortality or morbidity. The pooled effect estimate showed a mean difference of -7.42 kg compared to controls.
population_specificity: Patients with clinically significant obesity undergoing surgical procedures, primarily from European and North American centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of bariatric surgery on nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in obese patients through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery led to significant resolution of NAFLD features (steatosis, inflammation, ballooning degeneration, and fibrosis) in most patients, but 12% experienced new or worsening NAFLD features. The overall quality of evidence was very low.
population_specificity: Obese patients with NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of bariatric surgery as a treatment strategy for childhood obesity alongside lifestyle modifications and pharmacotherapy.
results_summary: The abstract mentions bariatric surgery as a treatment strategy but does not provide specific results regarding its effects, suggesting it is part of a broader discussion on obesity management.
population_specificity: Children with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether bariatric surgery reduces the risk of macrovascular events (coronary artery disease and cerebrovascular diseases) in patients with severe obesity and type 2 diabetes compared to usual care.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was associated with a lower incidence of macrovascular events (2.1% vs. 4.3%) and coronary artery disease (1.6% vs. 2.8%) at 5 years compared to nonsurgical patients, but no significant difference was found for cerebrovascular disease.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity (BMI ≥35) and type 2 diabetes, aged 19-79 years.
study_duration: Median follow-up of 4.7 years for surgical patients and 4.6 years for controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the 6-year rates of continuation, discontinuation, or initiation of antihypertensive and lipid-lowering therapy after bariatric surgery compared to a matched control group of obese patients.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery led to significantly greater reductions in antihypertensive and lipid-lowering therapy use compared to controls, with gastric bypass being more effective than sleeve gastrectomy. The proportion of patients starting new medication was also lower in the bariatric group.
population_specificity: Obese patients in France who underwent gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy in 2009, matched with control patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery in resolving glucose intolerance, diabetes, and PCOS in obese patients.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was found to be the most successful approach for obese patients with PCOS, with glucose intolerance, diabetes, and PCOS resolving in most cases during follow-ups. The study highlights its superior efficacy compared to other interventions like lifestyle modifications and insulin sensitizers.
population_specificity: Obese premenopausal women with PCOS and metabolic complications like insulin resistance and glucose intolerance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine which bariatric surgical procedure is most effective for achieving type 2 diabetes remission by comparing multiple surgical treatments.
results_summary: The network meta-analysis found that biliopancreatic diversion (BPD) and mini gastric bypass (mini-GBP) had the highest diabetes remission rates among the eight surgical procedures studied, though these procedures were less commonly performed.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus undergoing bariatric surgery or non-surgical treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe weight regain after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) surgery and compare different weight regain measures for their association with clinical outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that weight regain was highest in the first year after reaching nadir weight but continued over time, with the percentage of maximum weight lost being the strongest predictor of clinical outcomes. The percentage of participants who regained weight varied by threshold, with 67.3% regaining ≥20% of maximum weight lost five years after nadir weight.
population_specificity: 1406 adults (median age 47, 80.3% female, 85.6% white) who underwent RYGB surgery in the US, with a median BMI of 46.3 presurgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of bariatric surgery on obesity-related comorbidities and its impact on bone health.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery has a positive effect on obesity-related comorbidities but is detrimental to bone health. The underlying mechanisms are complex and heterogeneous, requiring further understanding for therapeutic intervention.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity (specifics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery in treating NAFLD in patients with HIV infection, particularly those with significant fibrosis or high risk for progression.
results_summary: The abstract suggests bariatric surgery can be considered for NAFLD treatment in high-risk HIV patients, but no specific efficacy or safety data are provided. It highlights the lack of studies on diet, exercise, or pharmacotherapy for this population.
population_specificity: Patients with HIV infection and NAFLD, particularly those with significant fibrosis, type 2 diabetes, metabolic syndrome, elevated transaminases, or pronounced necroinflammation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the rates of use and efficacy of stent placement for postoperative leaks following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Stent placement was used in 24% of leak cases, but 39% of those patients still required reoperation. Stent use was associated with a higher likelihood of readmission compared to reoperation alone.
population_specificity: Patients who experienced anastomotic or staple line leaks after bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential role of bariatric surgery, specifically Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB), in treating nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).
results_summary: Studies showed that RYGB improved all NASH histologic features at 1 year and was superior to adjustable gastric band in treating NASH. Randomized controlled trials and long-term studies are ongoing to further clarify its role in NASH therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of clip versus monopolar cauterization methods for staple line bleeding control in laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between clip and monopolar cauterization methods in terms of intraoperative and postoperative outcomes, including bleeding, operation time, and complications. Monopolar cauterization was deemed a safe and effective alternative to clipping for staple line bleeding control.
population_specificity: 70 morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, excluding those with previous upper gastrointestinal surgery, re-do procedures, or open surgeries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to subtype bariatric surgery patients based on temperament, emotion dysregulation, and disinhibited eating before and after surgery and assess the predictive value of these subtypes for long-term health outcomes.
results_summary: The study identified five pre-surgery and three post-surgery subtypes, which were significantly associated with varying levels of psychopathology. Post-surgery subtypes better predicted eating disorder psychopathology, depression, and quality of life but did not predict weight loss outcomes. Patients with pre-surgery self-control deficits were more likely to retain these deficits post-surgery.
population_specificity: 229 bariatric surgery patients from a multicenter registry.
study_duration: 3 years (pre-surgery, 2 years post-surgery, and 3 years post-surgery assessments)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of bariatric surgery in weight loss and its implications for cardiovascular health, alongside other preventive and treatment modalities for obesity.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on bariatric surgery but indicates it is briefly reviewed alongside other weight loss methods, suggesting it is considered as part of a broader discussion on obesity treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on obesity and cardiovascular risks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of bariatric surgery on intraocular pressure (IOP) and other ophthalmic parameters in obese women compared to non-obese controls.
results_summary: Obese women had significantly higher IOP at baseline than controls, which decreased after bariatric surgery, while no change was observed in the control group. The reduction in IOP correlated with weight loss and other obesity measures.
population_specificity: 22 obese women and 15 non-obese age-matched women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of FXR and TGR5 in regulating hepatic bile acid metabolism and their potential as targets for type 2 diabetes treatment.
results_summary: The study found that bile acid profile is a key regulator of metabolic homeostasis and that inhibiting Cyp8b1 expression, which determines bile acid profile, may be an effective therapeutic approach for type 2 diabetes. FXR and TGR5 were identified as regulators of bile acid metabolism and Cyp8b1 expression, offering a potential mechanism for treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on molecular mechanisms rather than a specific human population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term cardiovascular and renal outcomes of bariatric surgery in adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was associated with reduced all-cause mortality, cardiovascular disease risk, albuminuria, and progressive chronic kidney disease. Patients with poorer glycemic control and established microvascular disease preoperatively may benefit the most.
population_specificity: Adults with T2DM, particularly those with poorer glycemic control and established microvascular complications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the phenomenon of early worsening of diabetic retinopathy (DR) in various settings, including bariatric surgery, and discuss potential mechanisms.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that early worsening of DR can occur in patients undergoing bariatric surgery, likely due to rapid reductions in blood-glucose levels, but does not provide specific outcomes or data.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetes undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a brief DBT-ST group intervention adjunctive to bariatric surgery could reduce eating pathology and improve weight loss outcomes in pre-surgical candidates.
results_summary: The study found that participants in the DBT-ST plus TAU group showed reduced eating pathology and may be on a better weight loss trajectory compared to those receiving only TAU. The intervention demonstrated potential benefits as an adjunctive therapy for bariatric surgery candidates.
population_specificity: 95 bariatric surgery candidates (50 in DBT-ST + TAU group, 45 in TAU-only group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of bariatric surgery versus pharmacotherapies for obesity and type 2 diabetes, highlighting the potential of emerging multi-agonist drugs.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery typically results in significant and sustained weight loss, outperforming pharmacotherapies, which usually achieve only 5-10% weight reduction. Multi-agonist drugs show promise in bridging this gap by targeting multiple metabolic hormone receptors for improved outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity and type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: To evaluate the impact of adding omentectomy to bariatric surgery on metabolic outcomes such as body mass index, insulin, glucose, cholesterol, lipoproteins, and triglycerides.
results_summary: Adding omentectomy to bariatric surgery resulted in a minimal but statistically significant decrease in body mass index compared to bariatric surgery alone, but no overall improvement in metabolic outcomes was observed. The study concluded that the therapeutic use of omentectomy added to bariatric surgery is not warranted.
population_specificity: 366 patients from randomized controlled trials, with a median follow-up time of 1 year after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine changes in weight, comorbidities, and complications after bariatric surgery in obese adolescents.
results_summary: The study found weight loss, improvement in comorbidities, and complications across all procedures, though outcomes were inconsistently reported. The sleeve gastrectomy is increasing in use, while the lap band is decreasing.
population_specificity: Obese adolescents aged 11-21 years in the United States.
study_duration: Greater than 30 days of results reported.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if ileal interposition with duodenal diversion sleeve gastrectomy (II-DD-SG) is superior to standard medical treatment in achieving remission of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in obese patients.
results_summary: II-DD-SG led to significant remission of T2DM (86% complete remission at one year, 68% at five years) and reduced cardiovascular risk factors, while medical treatment showed minimal remission (only two patients). The surgery also normalized glucose levels and reduced insulin resistance.
population_specificity: Obese patients (BMI > 30) with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
study_duration: Follow-up periods of one and five years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether bariatric surgery is an effective intervention for obese asthma patients, particularly in severe or difficult-to-control cases.
results_summary: The study suggests that bariatric surgery may be a viable option for obese asthma patients in extreme cases, but it does not conclusively establish causality between obesity and asthma. The complexity of both conditions requires tailored therapeutic approaches.
population_specificity: Obese asthma patients, particularly those with severe or difficult-to-control asthma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery as a weight-loss intervention for patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) who are overweight or obese.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery, along with other interventions, can promote weight loss, reduce OSA severity, reverse comorbidities, and improve quality of life, though methodological limitations were noted in published studies.
population_specificity: Adult patients with OSA who are overweight or obese.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of metabolic surgery (RYGB vs. SG) in Asians, focusing on weight loss, T2DM resolution/improvement, and hypertension resolution.
results_summary: RYGB resulted in significantly higher % excess weight loss compared to SG, while T2DM resolution/improvement and hypertension resolution rates were similar between the two procedures.
population_specificity: Asian patients with obesity and/or type 2 diabetes mellitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the comparative effectiveness and safety of bariatric procedures in the Medicare-eligible population.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery resulted in greater weight loss compared to no surgery or conventional treatment, with lower overall mortality after 30 days but higher 30-day postoperative mortality. It was associated with reduced cardiovascular risk and improvements in respiratory, musculoskeletal, metabolic, and renal outcomes, though RYGB had more major complications than SG or AGB.
population_specificity: Medicare-eligible patients (older than 65 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between inflammation, obesity, and bariatric surgery, focusing on its physiological and molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: The study highlights bariatric surgery as an effective treatment for morbid obesity and type 2 diabetes, with evidence suggesting it improves inflammatory status in obese individuals. The correlation between obesity, inflammation, and type 2 diabetes is partially clarified.
population_specificity: Subjects with obesity, particularly those with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare 30-day outcomes between robotic-assisted and laparoscopic bariatric surgery procedures (RYGB and SG) to assess the clinical benefits of the robotic platform.
results_summary: The robotic approach showed significant reductions in postoperative bleeding, strictures, blood transfusions, anastomotic leaks, renal complications, and venous thromboembolism, with longer operative times but better outcomes after adjusting for confounders.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18-65 undergoing Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) or sleeve gastrectomy (SG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Helicobacter pylori (HP) infection increases the risk of postoperative complications, such as marginal ulcers, in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found that HP infection was associated with an increased risk of marginal ulcers and postoperative complications, though meta-analysis results were inconclusive (wide confidence intervals). The methodological quality of included studies varied from poor to good.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery with or without preoperative HP eradication therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the role of bariatric surgery in the development of de novo IBD and its impact on clinical outcomes and safety in patients with established IBD.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery in carefully selected IBD patients is technically feasible and probably safe, with acute flares observed in only four UC patients. De novo IBD developed in 80 patients post-surgery, mostly females, with symptoms appearing between 1 month and 16 years after surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity undergoing bariatric surgery, including those with established IBD and those who developed de novo IBD post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review therapeutic modalities to combat weight regain after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that weight regain is common after bariatric surgery, but various treatment options, including cognitive behavior therapy, appetite suppressants, and endoscopic procedures, can help reverse this trend. Revision surgery, though effective, may carry significant complications.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery and experienced weight regain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the unclear effects of weight loss interventions, including bariatric surgery, on gastrointestinal cancer outcomes in obese patients.
results_summary: The study found that the impact of bariatric surgery on gastrointestinal cancer in obese patients remains unclear, though potential mechanisms like reduced inflammation and improved insulin resistance were noted. Large clinical trials are underway to clarify these effects.
population_specificity: Obese patients with or at risk of gastrointestinal cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide guidelines for enhancing the quality of care in hernia treatment through metabolic and bariatric surgery by reviewing existing literature on obesity, obesity treatments, and hernia surgery.
results_summary: The study synthesized available knowledge, peer-reviewed literature, and expert opinion to suggest management strategies for effective and durable hernia repair in the context of obesity treatment. The guidelines are intended to be revised as additional evidence becomes available.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity requiring hernia treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and challenges of remote methods for long-term monitoring and postoperative interventions in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found that remote assessments and interventions can help overcome barriers like time, geography, and cost, improving access to care and outcomes for bariatric surgery patients. It highlighted both the advantages and challenges of these approaches.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery and required long-term follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and analyze the impact of bariatric surgery on periodontal clinical parameters, such as bleeding on probing, pocket depth, and clinical attachment levels.
results_summary: The study found increased periodontal inflammation and destruction at 6-month follow-up, but these differences were no longer significant at 12 months. The authors recommend periodontal screening and management for bariatric surgery patients to prevent further deterioration of periodontal status.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (n=250 at 6-month follow-up, n=191 at 12-month follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short- and mid-term outcomes of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) and Laparoscopic Sleeve Gastrectomy (LSG) in terms of efficacy, safety, and postoperative complications.
results_summary: RYGB showed significantly higher excess weight loss (EWL) and longer hospital stays compared to LSG, but LSG had fewer postoperative complications like hair loss. Both procedures had similar effects on diabetes mellitus and hypertension.
population_specificity: 62 patients who underwent either RYGB or LSG between 2010 and 2013 in a General Surgery Department.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of bariatric surgery on liver histology in NAFLD patients using the NAFLD activity score and compare the effects of sleeve gastrectomy and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly improved NAFLD activity scores, with both sleeve gastrectomy and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass showing notable improvements. No significant difference in histologic recovery was found between the two surgical methods.
population_specificity: 53 patients with NAFLD who underwent bariatric surgery at a university hospital in Germany.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical outcomes and intraoperative parameters between banded (BRYGB) and non-banded Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (NBRYGB) in patients with morbid obesity.
results_summary: The study found similar rates of complications, mortality, and remission of comorbidities (type 2 diabetes, hypertension, etc.) between BRYGB and NBRYGB, with comparable %EWL at 1 and 2 years. BRYGB showed increased %EWL at 5 years, but results were limited by few studies and lack of robust RCTs.
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the suitability of different bariatric surgery options for treating GERD in obese patients.
results_summary: The study found that sleeve gastrectomy may worsen or cause new GERD cases, while Roux-en-Y gastric bypass appears more effective for patients with both obesity and GERD. The presence of GERD should influence surgical choice.
population_specificity: Obese patients with or at risk of GERD.
